awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Models of Body Image and the Development of Mental Illness
awd_abstract_narration:
Body image disturbance and disordered eating behaviors accompany the deadliest of all mental illnesses and are increasingly prevalent. However, relative to women, researchers know comparatively little about how men experience eating disorders and body image. Scientific confidence in the validity of findings related to eating disorders also requires more representative samples that explore what variability there is in responses to these illnesses. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would enhance scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in discovering more effective methods for communicating science to the public. The findings of this research will be disseminated in such a way to aid researchers, clinicians, educators, and policymakers develop better policies and programs that anticipate and mitigate the effects of such cultural body attitudes on and mental health.

Lawrence Monocello, under the supervision of Dr. William Dressler of the University of Alabama, will explore cultural models of body image and the structural influences that they have on development of mental illness. Responding to uncertain and shifting economic environments, rapidly globalizing media, and changing gender norms, cultural ideas about men's bodies and body image in the United States increasingly focus on aesthetic presentation over physical prowess (i.e., valuing the body as an object to be looked at rather than a tool for athletics, labor, or protection). This kind of body attitude that significantly increases vulnerability to eating disorders. By contrast, this research studies a population of men already mired in a cultural system that venerates an aesthetic male body image.  This research will be conducted in Seoul, South Korea which is the economic, educational, and cultural capital, hosting its most successful companies, most celebrated universities, and major entertainment conglomerates. Researchers will focus on how men, ages 18-30, conceptualize male body ideals, attempt to enact them in their own bodies, and make meaning of their own individual body image experience within the larger cultural environment. They will develop a measure of body dissatisfaction that considers the culturally particular body ideals endorsed by that culture. Using demographic variables alongside measures of individuals' knowledge of male body ideals, concordance with body ideals, and body dissatisfaction, followed by long-term, in-depth interviews, the researchers will explore how each of these factors affects the development of disordered eating behaviors in men. Findings from this research will provide insight into how men living in cultural environments that endorse male aesthetics over brawn navigate pressures to conform to body image standards. These insights can then be used to develop interventions that will combat deadly body image-related disorders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lawrence Monocello has completed research for his dissertation "Cultural Consonance, Body Ideals, and Eating Disorders among Young South Korean Men" supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During the funded period, he spent six months in Seoul, South Korea at the Seoul National University Institute of Cross-Cultural Research. He was interested in understanding how young South Korean men think about their bodies, and how individual men's abilities to conform to cultural models of the ideal male body relate to different vulnerabilities to eating disorders.

Through participant-observation, cultural domain analysis, cultural consensus analysis, cultural consonance analysis, validated psychological scales for measuring body dissatisfaction and disordered eating beliefs and behaviors, and person-centered ethnographic interviewing, Monocello accomplished his goal of exploring the role of culture in vulnerability to eating disorders. This data is fundamental to bridging a gap between psychological and anthropological studies of body image when it comes to culture. Traditionally, psychologists have approached body image as a categorical variable and have often not distinguished it meaningfully from nationality; anthropologists argue that treating culture as a categorical variable suggests that differences in psychological outcomes are due to "being" a member of a culture and ignores intracultural diversity. Anthropologists have approached body image largely ethnographically, seeking to understand what about a given culture makes cross-cultural differences happen; psychologists argue that these methods are too time-consuming, expensive, and unreliable to be of use in scientific research. Therefore, Monocello's project attempted to combine ethnographic sensibility, emic validity, and attention to intracultural variation with the reliability and rigor of formal methodologies.

Monocello's data indicate that young South Korean men adopt cultural models of the ideal male body largely in line with the "flower boy" (kkonminam) style of presentation embodied in male Korean Pop (KPop) stars and actors, like the members of BTS. There are also men who pursue more muscular physiques, in line with a "beastly man" (chimsŭngnam) or "gym-rat" (helch'ang) presentation, although both the flower boy and beastly man/gym-rat physiques are pursued for their ornamental (aesthetic) rather than instrumental (physical ability) qualities. This is important because currently available psychological scales for measuring men's body image and vulnerability to eating disorders were developed on largely WEIRD (white/Western, educated, and from industrialized, rich, and democratic countries) samples with assumptions and beliefs about the body that are different from those enacted around the world more broadly. Particularly, models of Western masculinity often assume that men pursue muscularity as an instrumental endeavor, and these data show a different predisposition among Korean men, which may affect their vulnerability to disordered eating. In fact, the data show that young Korean men's ability to embody these cultural models affects their vulnerability to disordered eating beyond what individual psychology-level measures can account for, meaning that cultural variables measured on continuous scales should be an essential element of body image research in the future. Future publications will include detailed methods for replicating these findings and employing them among other cultures and settings.

Monocello's research in Seoul, South Korea forms the basis of his dissertation, which will be completed in 2022. This dissertation is an important contribution to anthropology, psychology, and body image research more broadly because it demonstrates how centering local systems of meaning in scientific research enhances our ability to understand globally diverse experiences of health-related phenomena. Moreover, it demonstrates the power of combining embodiment and cognitive anthropological methods and perspectives in investigating cross-culturally varied lived experiences of body image and eating disorders.
